results.title: Exploding Fist +  for ZX Spectrum 48/128/+2
results.creator_credit: Firebird Software, Telecomsoft and Beam Software
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette and cover in a plastic cassette case.
results.brief_description: Exploding Fist + [computer game]. Exploding Fist + is a side view beat ‘em up for up to three players. Players fight increasingly tougher opponents to rank as 10th Dan with a wide variety of karate kicks, punches, cartwheels and blocks. Once players have attained the rank of 10th Dan, they must then defend their title against more opponents. Players either score eight points or have the most before the bout ends. Points are scored by striking a fighter. The two highest scoring fighters progress to the next bout. If there is a tie, a replay bout will take place. After every two bouts, surviving players can play a bonus game where they throw ninja stars at demons hiding in a dark alley for additional points.
results.description: Exploding Fist + [computer game]. Exploding Fist + is a side view beat ‘em up for up to three players. Points are scored by striking a fighter. The two highest scoring fighters progress to the next bout. If there is a tie, a replay bout will take place. After every two bouts, surviving players can play a bonus game where they throw ninja stars at demons hiding in a dark alley for additional points.

results.title: Doc the Destroyer  for Commodore 64 & 128
results.creator_credit: Geoff Evans, Paul Kidd, Melbourne House and Beam Software
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover and manual booklet in a plastic cassette case
results.brief_description: Doc the Destroyer [computer game]. Doc the Destroyer is a side view, strategy arcade adventure in a post apocalyptic setting for one player. At the start of the game, players are given 60 points which they can distribute between five statistics Strength, Endurance, Intelligence, Luck and Charisma. As Doc, players are presented with various choices that determine your next action and some will throw the player into arcade styled combat.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Geoff Evans, Paul Kidd, Melbourne House and Beam Software

results.title: Demon Stalkers [Commodore 64 & 128]
results.creator_credit: Electronic Arts and Micro Forte Studios
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover, code wheel, warranty card & manual (paper booklet) in clear plastic cassette case
results.brief_description:
Demon Stalkers is an action RPG and editor/construction set game. It is similar to Atari’s Gauntlet. The player can choose either the hero, armed with throwing knives, or the heroine, armed with a crossbow who must travel through ninety-nine mazes before meeting the final demon. The game features different enemies as you progress through the mazes, with clues to progression built in. There is also a two-player co-operative mode. The in-built level editor uses pull-down menus and offers a high level of flexibility. As well as creating actual levels, the player can create an integrated storyline and game world, since the in-game text can also be edited.
The game shipped with a Magic Cipher consisting of three cardboard wheels that, when moved to the correct positions, revealed the passwords were needed to access some of the lower levels of the dungeon. Some of the vital text in the cipher is in a tone of blue that could not be photocopied at that point, making the cipher a basic anti-piracy measure.

Source: Play It Again website:
http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/demon-stalkers/

Last accessed: 14/04/2021

Original game developed by Micro Forte Studios for Commodore 64 and 128, published in 1987 by Electronic Arts.

results.title: Bedlam  for Commodore 64 & 128
results.creator_credit: GO! Media Holdings Ltd and Beam Software
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover in clear plastic cassette case
results.brief_description: Bedlam [computer game]. Bedlam is a top down vertical shooting scroller in a futuristic sci fi setting for one or two players simultaneously. Players pilot a vehicle shooting and dodging aliens and fighting boss ships.

results.title: Asterix and the Magic Cauldron [Spectrum 48/128 emulation]
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover and plastic cassette case.
results.brief_description:
Asterix and the Magic Cauldron is a single player adventure arcade game. Players control Asterix through various maps, collecting keys for locked doors and fighting Romans and boars in search of seven pieces of Getafix’s Magic Cauldron. Fights take place on a separate screen mode. Stamina bars for each combatant appear on the side of the window. Defeating the combatant adds it to the food tally. If Asterix loses the fight, the window closes and he loses a life. The same system is used when fighting the Roman soldiers and when Asterix picks up objects.

Obelix will only follow if Asterix has a supply of hams which can be obtained from fighting boars. Asterix starts with five lives and one dose of Magic Potion per game, which can be activated by double tapping the fire button.

Original game developed by Beam Software for ZX Spectrum 48K, published in 1986 by Melbourne House.

Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/asterix-and-the-magic-cauldron/

Last accessed: 1/05/2021

Obelix will only follow if Asterix has a supply of hams which can be obtained from fighting boars. Asterix starts with five lives and one dose of Magic Potion per game, which can be activated by double tapping the fire button.

results.title: America's Cup Challenge  for Amstrad
results.creator_credit: Armchair Entertainment, US Gold Pty Ltd and Micro Forte Studios
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover and manual in a plastic cassette case.
results.brief_description:
America’s Cup Challenge is a one to two player competitive sports simulation. The included manual contains a lot of information about the America’s Cup including yachting terminology, race legs, wind angles, sails and weather conditions. The player controls the crew of a racing yacht using the joystick, chosing the type of sail at the start of the race and then switching between three different modes, helmsman, sails selection and winching. As Helmsman, players control the yacht’s direction. Sail selection allows players to move the angle of the sail’s boom and the level of use of the spinnaker or genoa. The manual advises the use of a good quality robust joystick.

Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/arnies-americas-cup-challenge/
Last accessed: 14/04/2021

Original game developed by Micro Forté Pty. Ltd. for Commodore 64, published by Electronic Arts (USA) and U.S. Gold (Europe) in 1986.

results.title: How to Sell to Australia
results.brief_description: Since the beginning of television, Australian advertising has embedded itself into the national psyche through harnessing the moving image. Advertisers haven’t just sold products to Australian audiences, they’ve also built community, spread iconic catchphrases and created beloved characters.

constellations_primary.name: Short films that sell: the power of TV advertising
constellations_primary.description: The MTA’s "Dumb Ways to Die" has over 300 million views on YouTube with the campaign’s song known globally, having charted on iTunes in 28 countries. While light-hearted, at its core the hugely successful commercial carries a serious message: Be Safe Around Trains.

results.description: Advertising in Australia is unique, innovative and has a language all its own. Since the beginning of television in 1956 to today, Australian advertising has embedded itself into the national psyche by harnessing the power of the moving image. Through animation, live-action and apps, advertisers have been able to not just sell products to Australian audiences but also build community, spread iconic catchphrases and create beloved characters.

display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Pictures → MI-07. Birth of Television → MI-07-AV01

results.title: Ohnar 16MM Editor Viewer
results.brief_description: Film viewing and editing devices like the Ohnar provided amatuer filmmakers the ability to precisely edit their own home movies with relative ease. Popular among avid consumer-level filmmakers for their size, this 16mm film equipment allows hand cranking and has a convenient frame counting dial. The reel arms can be swivelled out and locked in place for use, and folded away for compact storage.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Foyer → Entry → FSF-03. MPL exterior

group_siblings.title: 16mm projector
group_siblings.material_description:
-Ditmar 16mm projector no 2072
 - Internal cloth bound board used as a platform to store inside box.
 - Grey cord w Aus plug and a black cord w Euro plug.
 - Detachable feed arm
 - Huile Oil Ol original cardboard box and glass oil bottle inside.  The oil bottle still has 3 mm of oil at bottom which is fluid.  The cork lid of the bottle also has a tiny metal straw protruding from it to gather the oil.
 - Singer (brand) oil pourer with a removable nozzle.  Not from this set, but owner must have used it as one of many methods to oil the projector.
 - Tiny metal funnel for pouring oil into oil dropper.
 - One glass dropper with rubber end which is stored inside a cylindrical tube with lid.
 - One clear plastic dropper with remnants of oil inside top round squeezer.
 - Australian plug with nothing connected.
 - A small Euro plug which is backed on to wood and slots in the back of the machine.
 - An old paper rag
 - 2 spare belts in very delicate wax paper bags.  One of rubber (hardened) and one finely coiled metal (which has a kink in it).

results.title: 16mm Film
results.brief_description: Most of the films in our collection are held on 16mm film, which was introduced in the 1920s as a cheaper alternative to the 35mm format and was widely adopted by amateur filmmakers. Because of its accessibility and popularity, it’s no surprise that we receive so many donations from the community, which along with the film itself, also comprises editing equipment and cameras. The Hanimex Eiki 16mm film projector displayed in this cabinet is typical of the kinds used in schools up until the 1980s, where films were screened in assembly halls to supplement standard learning in classrooms.

results.title: Lady Sarah (Rachel Weisz) costume from The Favourite
results.credit_line:
Cotton, linen, wool, nylon, canvas, leather, spandex, brass, plastic, leather, rubber, felt, feathers, bamboo and rag paper, synthetic polyester fibre

Courtesy of The Walt Disney Company
results.material_description: cotton, linen, wool, nylon, canvas, leather, spandex, brass, lastic, leather, rubber, felt, feathers, bamboo and rag paper, synethetic polyester fiber
results.brief_description: As Queen Anne’s childhood friend and confidant, Sarah Churchill (Rachel Weisz) wields enormous influence in 18th-century England and her clothing in The Favourite (2018) symbolises her power.

constellations_primary.name: Powerful women in the frame and behind the scenes
constellations_primary.description: Lady Sarah (Rachel Weisz) exudes power in The Favourite. These female filmmakers and actors do too.

results.description:
In The Favourite (2018), the only thing sharper than Lady Sarah’s (Rachel Weisz) wit is her silhouette. As Queen Anne’s childhood friend and confidant, Sarah Churchill wields enormous influence in 18th-century England, and her clothing symbolises her power.

This jacket often features in scenes where Sarah exerts her command, particularly while shooting with her rival, Abigail (Emma Stone). Costume designer Sandy Powell made it in a similar shape to men’s shooting jackets – to demonstrate Sarah’s liberation from the gender politics of the time – yet kept a feminine touch. Sarah also wears breeches as she navigates (and controls) the male-dominated world of military strategy and domestic politics.
description_for_label:

This jacket often features in scenes where Sarah exerts her command, particularly while shooting with her rival, Abigail (Emma Stone). Costume designer Sandy Powell made it in a similar shape to men’s shooting jackets – to demonstrate Sarah’s liberation from the gender politics of the time – yet kept a feminine touch. Sarah also wears breeches as she navigates (and controls) the male-dominated world of military strategy and domestic politics.
